newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish investor club investments up 39 pct in H1.
newsitem.headline: Danish investor club investments up 39 pct in H1.

text.p: Danish investor clubs' combined investments rose 39 percent during the first-half of 1997 to a total 76 billion crowns, according to Danish Investment Association Council data released on Monday.

"Investment in Danish bonds has shown the greatest growth since the end of 1996, with 10 billion crowns in bond-based investments in the first six months of this year," council director Carsten Mahler said in a statement.
"Danish bonds account now for an overall 41 percent of all our invested funds, some two percent up on end-1996," he said.
Council statistics showed that investments in foreign shares rose in the six month period to 37 percent from 35 percent of entire disposable investment funds.
Total investments in Danish shares accounting for nine percent as opposed to 10 percent of total investments at end-1996, it said.
Total foreign bond holdings fell to eight percent from 11 percent of all bond investments by the 17 investment clubs under the council.

Danske Invest and Uni-Invest, which are affiliated respectively to Den Danske Bank and Unidanmark, the country's two biggest banks, administer 57 percent of investor association funds. --Ole Mikkelsen, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969654
